text:
Breaking: State utility regulators on Thursday approved a settlement that will require Southern California Edison customers to foot about $1.7 billion in claims from the 2017 Thomas Fire and the resulting 2018 Montecito Debris Flows. cal.news/4htfRCq

📸 Jae C. Hong, AP
comment: Can't wait! 🧾

A for-profit corporation causes immense damage to the community it serves and that same community now gets saddled with covering the costs of the corporation’s malfeasance, instead of its shareholders. Following this logic, shouldn’t the utility just be a publicly owned nonprofit?

As always, that money is coming out of people's electricity bills.  It will make electricity more expensive, and fewer people will switch from gas to electric, which is exactly the opposite of the outcome we want.

author: unhaengels.bsky.social
text:
I think about that day now and then.

But with the wildfires raging in California recently, the memories came back clearer—the fire that burned down the building where I lived in Boston in 1998.

It was my real first apartment, not a sublet.

Ben Brown was killed by a 79-year-old driver on Rose St. 

www.berkeleyside.org/2024/11/19/b...
The worst indictment here is that we as a society force elderly to have to wield deadly weapons they cannot handle because we offer no alternative form of transportation
Don’t forget young men driving like GTA, pickup trucks so high you can’t see the road, and everyone else watching cat videos on their phones.
I worry about this so much with my parents. They refuse to consider moving some place less car dependent.
Re-test at 30,  retest at 50, at 60, at 65, and every 5 years beyond.  A full driving test as if it's your first time and actually fail people who can't do it.
this country should start requiring driving and eye tests at age 50 and repeat them every 5 years to get ones license renewed

It seems like every time a driver hits and kills an entire family or mom with a stroller recently, they are elderly. This case comes to mind. 

Driver charged with felony vehicular manslaughter in SF crash that killed an entire family | KTVU FOX 2 search.app/HdsSjHbKtnwK...
Journalists can contribute by writing more like this article instead of suggesting pedestrians were killed by sentient cars.
IMO this issue of too-old-to-drive is going to be bad - especially in sprawling cities and poor transit.  We're seeing it here too.
My friend from HS was killed by a 77 y/o in San Diego last year and she got 1 year of house arrest and two years probation.  She fled the scene and left him to die in the street.
It’s frightening how often I see a car going way too slow or weaving while cycling and it ends up being an elderly person. It’s only going to get worse as the boomers age.

I once found a study indicating that driving ability plummets steeply after age 80, cannot find it now. All of the older driver pages you find with a cursory Google search chirp about how sharp some people are at that age, without acknowledging that majority are not.

author: andywx80.bsky.social
text: Hard to find good analogs these days for S2S outlooks, but fire managers rely on them to gauge potential impacts. Several dates from Feb 89 show up in week 2. Interesting contrast from the OH Vly to the Gulf in 89. Using 89, 11, 14, 17, 18 tentatively for Feb. Not great if this year is similar.
comment: Continuing to watch for potentially significant flooding in the Miss. and Ohio Valleys heading into Feb., along with increasing and notable severe weather outbreaks. Many of these analogs featured bad spring fire seasons from the Southern Plains to the Southeast, as well. A lot to sort out though.
Are analogs useful given the change in underlying conditions caused by GHG emissions? Was the SST cold spot off of Greenland a thing in 1989?

author: gspeng.bsky.social
text: This is why I am waiting for iron-air home batteries for my home in a dense neighborhood. We get into a vicious cycle of needing solar panels+home batteries for reliable electricity in WUI sprawl. But inevitable WUI fires become toxic dumps.  www.latimes.com/california/s...
comment: Sure, but aren’t most people going to end up using their car as their backup battery, once car-to-grid becomes reasonably widespread? Few are going to pay for home battery and an EV if the EV in their driveway does both. So, it comes down to EV battery technology.

Batteries because our electric distribution system is less dependable. Dense urban next to forest has been risky.  A neighbor near me burned due to a rental EV.  I have visited mines and CN factories, and do not want panels.  I wonder how the insurance companies will consider other battery types.

There is a lot of stuff in a home that becomes toxic after it burns. Iron-air sounds promising, but it would fill a big yard. Battery safety is largely dictated by system design rather than battery chemistry. Important to get both right for safety in dense residential.

author: charlest.bsky.social
text:
Ben Hamlington, a NASA research scientist specializing in climate change impacts, lost his home in the Eaton Fire, which destroyed over 9,000 structures in Altadena, California.

Losing his home has erased the line between his job and his life, he says.

www.npr.org/2025/01/23/n...
comment: Hamlington's experience underscores the urgent need for climate action to mitigate the worsening effects of climate change, emphasizing the growing personal and societal impact of these disasters and the difficult choices communities face in adapting to a changing climate.

author: npr.org
text: An economist's harrowing escape from fire, and her big ideas to rescue California from its insurance doom spiral.
comment: It's helpful to see the why, but I'm not agreeing with the how.  Building back better is only possible with more money, and that sounds like government, not homeowners.  It seems that if government or some other collective doesn't subside the areas in question, then it will be only for the rich.
I hope North Carolina is taking notes bc the insurance industry wants to raise and cancel all the storm policies too.
W need more people like him. Project that help not make it political
Start w Newsom. Should have, could have but didn't.

Why isn't this a root cause discussion? The problem isn't premium pricing regulations.

What's driving the rising fire threat? Doesn't seem likely to be the individuals living in these areas.

What could be a more efficient resolution than simply enriching insurers?

#sciencesky any thoughts? 🥹
Have we heard when Trump is going to turn the valve? #TurnTheValve
Still stunned with all that eucalyptus, and wood sided construction, the Claremont survived.

The ICC does now offer "read-only" access to the CFC for free, but if unsuspecting people look at it, they'll still see a claim (which I think is bogus) that "no part of this publication may be reproduced, distributed, or transmitted" without ICC permission.

author: limot.bsky.social
text:
California firefighters were complaining bitterly that controlled (prescribed) burns had been outlawed.

I leaned about controlled burns from the controversy, not in class. It was scientifically rather interesting, fighting fire with fire.

Why were controlled burns outlawed? Environment lobbies.
comment:
Controlled fires are not outlawed in California; they are difficult to get approved.

Newsome and the State legislature have passed bills to make it easier; federal guidelines on pollution require a lengthy approval process.

My comment hardly seemed block-worthy.

Here I was thinking ok, perhaps there exists one reasonable Californian who can actually engage in rational dialog. Proof by counter-example.

Oh, well.

And fire breaks, which exist, meant nothing in these fires. And sprinklers actually led to water pressure drops in Palisades. They hurt.

author: starling42.bsky.social
text:
Just so big tree lovers don't worry  about fire damaging the General Sherman tree in Southern California:

As of January 2025, the General Sherman Tree, the world's largest tree by volume, has not suffered fire damage.
comment: The Redwood Mountain Grove, for instance, lost an estimated 974 to 1,574 large sequoias due to the KNP Complex Fire.  This highlights the importance of protective measures and prescribed burns in safeguarding these ancient trees.

These efforts were successful, and the General Sherman Tree remained unharmed. 

In contrast, other sequoia groves experienced significant losses.

During the 2021 KNP Complex Fire, firefighters took proactive measures to protect this iconic giant sequoia. They wrapped the tree's base in protective foil and removed surrounding vegetation to reduce fire risk.
Its 250+ miles away. Not exactly “at risk” from fires in SoCAL.

comment:
Cont from last post. 
In this regard, wildfires are bad, but to me, quakes are worse cuz they're a bolt out of the blue, and while fires burn buildings, quakes drop freeways making recovery that much harder. 2 miles worth of elevated interstate 10 had to be demolished before recovery could begin.

The problem isn't year round fire season per se, it's that everyone can see them coming and still they do nothing. I'm not just talking about authorities, but utility managers and worse: home owners. During one season firefighters had a rule: if you brush cleared, we'll fight to save what's yours.

text:
Well, here’s a concrete question-  the NYP article says that “Instead of fire-hardening the park, the city…was ordered by the California Coastal Commission to reverse the whole project and replant the rare herb.”  

Is “reverse the whole project” an accurate characterization of what happened?
comment: That isn't a question that can be answered from the LAT and CN accounts, right? Do you have other reports to draw on?

author: walterolson.bsky.social
text: It documents that a modest attempt to harden the chaparral zone by e.g. widening fire access roads was stopped fast and drew a huge fine. I don't see anyone claiming this incident caused the fires. I do see plenty of centrists criticizing the sort of California regulatory kudzu illustrated here.
comment: regulatory kudzu is a beautifully apt phrase

That characterization doesn’t seem to be supported by the cited articles, and there’s no indication the Oliveira’s research went beyond those articles.  

The article just seems too biased to be trustworthy or helpful. 

(Btw, I do appreciate your taking the time to engage on this)

author: lizzs-beachgirl.bsky.social
text:
1. Building features- California Palisades fires - I’ve heard some comments about the way houses were built there which contributed to them catching fire (I realise this was a small factor but I’m curious). 
Such as open eaves, attic vents, chimneys, as access points for embers.
comment: 2. I don’t think Australian houses have those US features, unless maybe in old suburbs like Mosman. My 30yr old house on Sunshine Coast has no vents, no chimney, closed eaves with soffit, gutter guard to keep leaf litter away. Brick walls, tile roof. Aluminium windows with thermal break.

author: elvis-sinosic.bsky.social
text:
"They have never had extreme fire weather like this in a January before"

California has experienced wildfires in January prior to 2025. Historical data indicates that from 1900, approximately 170 fires occurred in January, which accounts for about 0.8% of all fires in California.
